Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <jintaa> The answer lies somewhere in between. It would need to be wielded more like a scalpel than a hammer. I believe this is exactly what the cpu equalization mechanism intrinsic to Verus was meant to address, and I believe it is one such example of an elegant attempt to mitigate the dangers you speak of. Whether it's enough is a question that will have to be continually addressed, as we've already seen with the necessitation of Verushash 2.0 to counter the nebulous fpga's. That response by @miketout and the team, I believe, is emblematic of the kind of approach that will be required to address the big questions we will continue to face- vision, courage, innovation and steadfastness in pursuit of the ultimate goal.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> Extremely well put, @jintaa!

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <Oink> Although the idea was inspired by the massive drop in network has seen last monday, your answer made it clear to me that this system should not be used to arbitrarily block out high end systems. The fact that I am using the word arbitrarily implies that we would centrally decide which hardware is acceptable to use and which are not. A blockchain is a consensus system, if this system is to be used in a chain, the parameters the system uses must be acquired by consensus too (a PBaaS poll could come in handy for this).
The mechanism is not meant to cripple a chains developement, although I see the possibility of doing so if the paramaters are too strict. In fact I gave the example of too strict parameters myself by tuning down the profit model so far that a Pi would have the same profit chances as a FPGA. I fully agree we  are depending on peoples greed to keep the PoW securing the network in place. What I intend to achieve is a more evenly distribution of the hashpower, by limiting the centralized upscaling of hashpower (just like government do with anti-monopoly regulations) and promoting adoption of this blockchain by more people by offering them a fair chance to profit from securing the chain on their own, with *relatively* low spec devices that everybody can afford, or in  already own.
Bear in mind that if and only if the parameters are set correctly, it would only effectively restrict your earning if a desired the network hashrate is large enough to effectively secure the chain. The mechanism is it's own profitability mechanisme: if the hashrate is high, it's not profitable enough for some people to be enticed to mine, but if the hashrate is low the profitability will entice them to hop on. It is basically making use of the profit-switching mining conduct people are displaying today.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <Oink> The upgrade to Verushash 2.0 is indeed an elegant way to mitigate the dangers of hash power centralization. The effect it has does indeed seem to have the reuired effect. We cannot expect, however, for every chain to adopt this algorithm, nor do I wish to. (If only one algorithm would survive, it would be everybodies focus to find loopholes in it). The mechanism could be implemented on any PoW based algorithm, should the developers wish to do that, because the mechanism is not working on hardware level or algorithm level, but on blockchain level.
It could also provide an extra security for 100% PoW chains, since the needed 51% for a succesful attack would be much harder to achieve. Also it could help in the (idealistic, I admit) goals of global energy preservation. In this context I'll make a comparison to a known practise in the navy:
`On any submarine there's an ongoing hunt to identify and eleminate the loudest noise, in order to make the boat more silent and less detectable. Once the loudest noise is eliminated another existing noise is labeled as the loudest noise.` Society is doing the exact same thing in energy consumption rigt now: from the transition from filament lightbulbs to LED light bulbs to the transition from gas guzzlers to energy efficient cars.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <Oink> I predict a time where blockchain mining is considered a waist of energy (In fact China already named it as one of their reasons in trying to reduce the national blockchain industry), despite the profits it yields.
Humans insatiable urge to deplete (natural) resources for monetary gain is a big factor that drives our global economy, but at the same time puts that economy at risk, due to depletion of said resources. I'ld hate to see the same happen to the blockchain economy.
Bear in mind that I put up my original piece to start a discussion, so I welcome all feedback, positive and negative.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> @Oink perhaps toying with the cooldown time (lowering it) would still give everyone the same chance in a sense like you describe but better machines would still average out to slightly higher rewards due to their ability to find the blocks faster when they are not in "cooldown mode" averaged out over time?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> Dunno, still like the uniqueness of the idea and agree in the value of diversification

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Oink> Better machines will always have a higher chance of finding and submitting a block after the cooldown time is over. So their rewards will always remain higher that low end systems. It's just a matter whether it is economically viable to keep them mining on a chain that caps their profits.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> Right, so due to averaging out over time, you may be able to mitigate the issue described above and still maintain a capitalist friendly model

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> I guess tweaking the cool-down time could allow you to have some control

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <zpajk> I fail to see how a cool down could work other than be a gate on an open field to go around. I feel like I‚Äôm missing the point.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> If when you get a block reward, there is a say 10 minute cool down before you can get another one, then someone with a powerful machine that finds a block every second will have to wait just as long as someone who has a less powerful machine that finds a block every minute. Basically

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <zpajk> I mean, we‚Äôre focusing on privacy as a key word. It‚Äôs hard to limit something unless you start collecting data on devices/people.

@Godballz Poor pool owners. ^^

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> It would be built into consensus I believe

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> I don't think it would have anything to do with identifying anyone

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Oink> @zpajk using mechanisms that exist in blockchains, I believe this can be done without gathering any data. A mining reward could be payed using a P2SH address (already used to govern the time locked blocks on our network) and using those conditions to allow or deny the submission of a block.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <zpajk> So no pools allowed? That benefits large players.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <zpajk> Or address change on every won block?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Oink> That depends on how strict the parameters would be applied. But it could be used to avoid concentration of power, which pools are too. I think it would actually not benefit large players, because they will be economically be restricted more than small solo miners, that don‚Äôt find a block within a day anyway.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Oink> It actually favors large amounts of small miners, as opposed to a small number of big miners.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Oink> Address change on every block would be something worth investigating. It could undermine the entire idea indeed.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> It could just be a cool down on newly created addresses if that's doable?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> Same cool down no matter what

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <zpajk> Seeing how power/hash can be split and mimicked I‚Äôd say that‚Äôs a no go as well. This is why I like Verushash 2, which has very good hardware and software balance. It may not be perfectly balanced against fpgas, but it‚Äôs doing a great job.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Oink> I agree @Godballz , but what if you create the addresses in advance?

Author: Gateway#3763

Author: Gateway#3763

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> Hmm

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Oink> I agree on both points @zpajk . That‚Äôs why I‚Äôm hoping for a golden idea to emerge from this discussion.

Author: Gateway#3763

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> No I mean if any new address joins the network it is subject to a cool-down

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> Would that compromise privacy? Maybe I'm missing something

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Oink> I misunderstood your post on keep al addresses connected to the chain. I interpreted it as the chain keeping track of connecting addresses from 1 wallet.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> Oh gotcha

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Oink> My interpretation is a non-acceptable solution to me, from a privacy point of view.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Oink> Basically as I see it right now, the idea has a fatal flaw: which is switching to a different address!

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> So a cool-down for those addresses joining wouldn't help with that? It would at least force anyone trying to game the system to keep every one of those addresses connected all the time

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Oink> If you create say 150 addresses in one go and switch to them sequentially, they would all meet the age specifications after the cooldown is done, leaving you free to switch mining to the next 'free' address as soon as you hit a block. I can imagine this being done using a script of sorts.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Oink> A cooldown on address would ony work if you're prohibited to use any other address. I think that's a restriction we don't want.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Oink> I do agree however, that keeping the addresses connected while the cooldown takes place would seriously hinder efforts to play the system

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> Maybe not the same cooldown but there is no way to put a time restriction on any address change

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> Oh okay yeah I agree it really would just make things more difficult

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> Might be a bad idea but just throwing this out there - what about every x blocks automatic cool down along with mention system

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Oink> The only option I can think of to overcome this is to include a hash of the unique hardware ID into the P2SH reward payment, to exclude the hardware from submitting a block for the durating of the cooldown. Including it in a P2SH payment basically means it stays private. But I cannot see all the implications of this.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Oink> If I'm correct, it would mean that Pools are back in business...

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <zpajk> Not sure how the consensus algorithm works, but I would think there's only 2 points of keeping track of addresses, either when submitting solutions or Coinbase payouts, as such P2SH. But that doesn't hinder anyone from changing address upon winning rewards.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <zpajk> It's a hard harmony to achieve between hardware, software, algorithm and profit. Any of them change there's going to be fluctuations. üòÑ

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Oink> Submitting a hardware ID (hashed or not) into P2SH conditions is not going to work either: simply switch to a different address: the P2SH conditions on the previous address aren't valid for this address... However, it would enable pool mining.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Oink> @Godballz Can you explain a bit more about the *every x block automatic cooldown*? I don't really grasp the idea (yet)?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> Well it wouldn't stop anything actually it would just make more of an inconvenience if say 30% of your list of addresses are unusable. Not really a good solution at all tbh. Just figured maybe another obstacle but that'd give it's own tradeoffs I'm sure.  @Oink

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Oink> Agree. It would effect everybody on the chain, also the people with just 1 address.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> I guess single address people could build that time into their in-between blocks time it wouldn't change much so long as it didn't affect security

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Oink> I may have thought of something that may be viable: What if we submit a hash into the found block that represents the miner (h/w + s/w ID combined into 1 hash) in a First In First Out string on the chain and let the blockchain itself determine if the admitted block is from a miner who's hashed ID is present in that string?  That would make it fully consensus based.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Oink> It is basically the same mechanism that determines if a UTXO is spent or not.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> So long as the ID can't be spoofed. There  could be big incentive to find a workaround

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <006vl> Hello,

I have some questions regarding project. I mean no offense by anything I say, as I am misunderstanding a lot of things given my lack of knowledge.

I can't really wrap my head around what VerusCoin is doing. It seems like a hybrid (PoW with unique hash and PoS) coin, with the ability to create individual blockchains.
Doesn't the goal of this project conflict with Komodoplatform, its parent chain? What's the utility of making another platform, when the parent chain is also geared towards accessibility towards new blockchain creators? What is the utility of this coin?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> Hi, thanks for the question. In fact, no one, not Komodo or any other project is doing what Verus is doing.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> Verus is part of the Komodo ecosystem, which is a system that can support many chains working together, however a project may decide to leverage that capability. For Verus, it was a great starting point for public blockchains as a service.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> PBaaS, is consistent with the concept of the Komodo ecosystem, but a fully decentralized model that has no one but miners, stakers, node operators and others that support the network in exchange for earning across many publicly merge mined and staked chains that can also engage in high volume (additional new technology in progress) cross-chain operations with enhanced programmability . They also still have the ability to be notarized and interoperate with the rest of the Komodo ecosystem as well.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> PBaaS chains are run entirely by the Verus network plus the PBaaS chain's network and require Verus to launch and auto-notarize. They can be started very quickly, run for days, can prove all blocks and transactions independently with a single number, which can serve as an archive root for polls and elections or archived business chains, and they get all the benefits of Verus itself. They get a provably 51% hash attack resistant Verus proof of power algorithm. They get independence and separability from the Verus ecosystem. They get Komodo interoperability, the same CPU-mineability and field tested FPGA-equalization of VerusHash 2.0, and they will have the ability to be reserve currencies with protocol based, market driven conversion. Verus is basically pushing the envelope of the decentralized Komodo model, and making it easy for any project to create single-chain currencies and applications as part of a decentralized, merge mineable, Komodo compatible system, or many-chain applications that can create and archive chains as part of the application.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> PBaaS will allow anyone or any project to start a chain without any server account by leveraging the ability of each and every miner in the entire Verus network to merge mine up to 15 chains at a time with the same hash power, another uniquely Verus capability, as is the fully decentralized, cross-chain interoperability protocol that uses a single number at any point in a chain to prove any block, block power, or transaction on the entire chain. PBaaS reserve currencies will allow people to convert Verus to a PBaaS chain's currency and back, similar to how Bancor works for those projects that want to share liquidity with the rest of the Verus ecosystem, also a uniquely Verus capability, but in chains and projects that can remain compatible with the rest of the Komodo ecosystem as well.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> Verus is a community project with a Vision and people helping to make it real. It is not a business and does not have an organization behind it charging for its utility. It is a decentralized protocol built by blending Komodo, Zcash, and Verus technologies, and similar to the Komodo philosophy can be used by a project without any central entity being paid. Also, as with Komodo, you can certainly get help from people in the ecosystem and easily provision Komodo notarization and interoperability as well.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <006vl> Thank you for taking your time to provide me with such a detailed answer.
I think this is the answer I was looking for. This is actually an amazing project.

JL777 was talking very highly about you and this project, so I thought I would check it out. I see why now.
